sources.name: Consumer Protection Law (Royal Decree No. M/66 of 2018)
Commercial Courts Law (Royal Decree No. M/93 of 2020)
Law of Procedure Before Sharia Courts

steps.title: Filing of Consumer Complaint or Commercial Claim
steps.description: Consumer complaint or commercial claim is filed with the Ministry of Commerce or directly before the competent court through the Najiz platform.

steps.title: Preliminary Review and Notification
steps.description: Authority or court reviews the complaint for jurisdiction and completeness and notifies the opposing party.

steps.title: Submission of Responses and Evidence
steps.description: Opposing party submits responses, documents, and evidence within prescribed timelines.

steps.title: Settlement or Reconciliation Attempt
steps.description: Authority or court encourages settlement or reconciliation between the parties prior to adjudication.

conditional_branches.effect: Dispute resolved and settlement documented in compliance with Sharia

typical_outcomes: Partial settlement with remaining issues adjudicated
No settlement and continuation to judgment
dependencies: Nature and value of the claim
Quality of contractual or transactional evidence
Compliance of settlement terms with Sharia principles

failure_risks: Failure to comply with procedural timelines
Settlement terms conflicting with Sharia principles

steps.title: Hearings and Evidence Review
steps.description: Court conducts hearings, reviews documentary evidence, and hears submissions from the parties.

steps.title: Judgment
steps.description: Court issues judgment resolving the consumer or commercial dispute in accordance with Sharia and statutory law.

steps.title: Appeal
steps.description: Aggrieved party may appeal the judgment before higher courts as permitted by Saudi law.

documents_required: Regulatory filings or inspection reports (if applicable)

escalation_paths.condition: Appeal on points of law or Sharia compliance
